title: Ksp of AgCl in distilled vs tap water exp

content.question:
<math alttext="A g C l solid is in equilibrium with A g with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous; K sub s p is equal to 1.8 times 10 to the negative 10 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>⇄</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="1.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Shown above is information about the dissolution of <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in water at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. In a chemistry lab a student wants to determine the value of <math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the molar solubility of <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, by measuring <math alttext="the molar concentration of A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in a saturated solution prepared by mixing excess <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and distilled water. How would the results of the experiment be altered if the student mixed excess <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with tap water (in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of C l with a negative 1 charge equals 0.010 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>0.010</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) instead of distilled water, and the student did not account for the <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> in the tap water?

choices.label: The value obtained for <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> would be too small because <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions would be attracted to the <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the <math alttext="A g C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> crystals, thus preventing water molecules from reaching the crystals.

The value obtained for <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> would be too small because less <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> would dissolve because of the common ion effect due to the <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> already in the water.

The value obtained for <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> would be too large because more <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> would dissolve because of the attractions between <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> crystals and the <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the water.

The results of the experiment would not be altered because <math alttext="0.010 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is such a small concentration of <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions and thus has no effect on the dissolution of <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The value obtained for <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> would be too small because less <math alttext="A g C l solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AgCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> would dissolve because of the common ion effect due to the <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> already in the water.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
